title: Nephew discovered video of uncle’s ‘sex game murder’ after coroner ruled death ‘accidental’
text:
Jason Marshall (R) was jailed for 39 years for the sadistic killing of Mr Fasoli

A fresh inquest has been ordered into the death of a man who was wrongly found to have died accidentally before video footage of him being tortured and suffocated came to light.

Peter Fasoli was murdered in January 2013 by Jason Marshall, who posed as an MI5 agent then stripped, gagged, handcuffed and smothered the 58-year-old with cling film after meeting him on dating website Badoo.

Marshall, then 29, was jailed in September 2017 for a minimum of 39 years for the ‘sadistic’ killing of Mr Fasoli, which was only discovered when his nephew found harrowing webcam footage of the murder on his uncle’s computer hard drive.

For almost two years the victim’s family believed his cause of death was an accidental fire that started in his apartment.

The London Fire Brigade were called to Mr Fasoli’s home in Northolt on January 7 2013. He was found unresponsive and taken to hospital but was pronounced dead on arrival.

At the time of his death ‘no evidence of an assault or a restraint by a third party’ was found in a post-mortem examination, and a report from the London Fire Brigade concluded that the fire was likely accidentally caused by an ‘LED bulb falling onto bedding’.

Peter Fasoli’s murdered evaded justice for two years after a coroner ruled he died accidentally (Picture: PA)

At the High Court in London on Tuesday, two senior judges quashed the coroner’s original verdict of an accidental death and ordered that a new inquest must take place.

During Marshall’s trial at London’s Old Bailey, jurors heard the killer stole nearly £800 from his victim before setting alight his bungalow to cover his tracks.

He went to Mr Fasoli’s flat on the evening of January 6 2013 on the pretext of bondage sex, and dressed as a law enforcement agent complete with handcuffs, police utility belt, holster and latex gloves.

He ‘arrested’ Mr Fasoli ‘for being a spy’ and threatened to cut his tongue with a large hunting knife to extract his PIN numbers.

He then used his victims bank details to book a flight to Italy, where he killed a second man and attacked a third before finally being caught.

The trial judge at the Old Bailey said Marshall, who used gay dating app Badoo to stalk his victims, ‘felt no remorse whatsoever’ for the killing of Mr Fasoli.

Judge Nicholas Hilliard QC also raised concerns that the police failed to detect the murder for nearly two years.

Jason Marshall inside Peter Fasoli’s flat on the night he killed him (Picture: PA)

The judge said that social media records showed Marshall was coming to Mr Fasoli’s home on the evening of the murder and that Mr Fasoli’s bank card was used after his death.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He said the wrongly recorded cause of death should be a lesson for authorities to look at whether procedures for investigations are sufficiently comprehensive and robust in such circumstances.

After the trial, lawyers acting on behalf of the Senior Coroner for West London applied to quash the original verdict so a fresh inquest can be carried out.

At the high court today, Lord Justice Hickinbottom, sitting with Mrs Justice Lambert, said the case concerned ‘quite extraordinary facts’.

He said: ‘In all the circumstances, it is clearly necessary and desirable in the interests of justice that a fresh inquest and investigation should take place’.
